arguments.claim: Facts establish full satisfaction: authorities conditioned payment on full discharge, appellants complied despite reluctance

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated April 15,1958, the appellate court came to a contrary conclusion and held that on the evidence, oral and documentary, given in the case it was clearly established that the appellants accepted the sum of Rs. 20 lacs

holdings.text: There was accord and satisfaction; appellants gave full discharge of their claim upon receiving Rs. 20 lacs

holdings.text: Section 63 of the Indian Contract Act applies; acceptance of lesser payment from third party discharges whole claim per illustration (c)

anchor.surface_text: Section 63 of the Indian Contract Act reads Every promisee may dispense with or remit, wholly or in part, the performance of the promise made to him, or may extend the time for such performance or may accept instead of it any satisfaction which he thinks fit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual application to facts where appellants accepted Rs.20 lacs in full satisfaction, discharging debt owed by respondent

anchor.surface_text: A reference may also be made in this connection to s. 41 of the Contract Act under which when a promisee accepts performance of the promise from a third person. he cannot afterwards enforce it against the promiser.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supports discharge under s.63; statutory words leave no room for doubt despite English authority requiring debtor ratification

holdings.text: Appellants not entitled to sue respondent for balance after accepting Rs.20 lacs in full satisfaction

anchor.surface_text: The appellants having accepted payment in full satisfaction of their claim, are not entitled to sue the respondent for the balance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show appellants knew payment conditioned on full satisfaction endorsement and complied

holdings.text: Day v. McLea not applicable as facts differ; here clear condition of full satisfaction imposed and accepted

holdings.text: Neuchatel Asphalte Co. v. Barnett not applicable; facts entirely different with no ambiguity in condition

anchor.surface_text: The facts of the case before us are entirely different. The appellants were clearly and unambiguously told that unless they gave a full satisfaction of their claim, they would not be paid the amount.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent distinguished: no covering letter ambiguity or partial account pretense; clear full satisfaction required

anchor.surface_text: One is the decision in Day v. Mc Lea  1 . In that case the plaintiffs made a claim against the defendants for a sum of money as damages for breach of companytract the defendants sent a cheque for a less amount stating that it was in full payment of all demands. The plaintiffs kept the cheque stating they did so on account and brought an action for  1   1899  32 Q. B. D. 610-613.

precedents.cited_proposition: Keeping a cheque for a lesser amount sent as full payment is not conclusive of accord and satisfaction as a matter of law, but a question of fact depending on the terms upon which it was kept.
precedents.cited_holding: keeping, the cheque was number as a matter of law companyclusive that there was an accord and satisfaction of the claim but that it was a question of fact on what terms the cheque was kept.

precedents.citation: Neuchatel Asphalte Co. Ltd. v. Barnett

anchor.surface_text: The second decision relied on on behalf of the appellants Neuchatel Asphalte Co. Ltd. v. Barnett  2  also proceded on a similar ground. precedents.case_name: Neuchatel Asphalte Co. Ltd. v. Barnett
precedents.cited_proposition: No intention to accept lesser payment as full satisfaction where circumstances show otherwise, such as accompanying letter indicating payment on account.

anchor.surface_text: In Hirachand Punam chand v. Temple  1  the father of a debtor wrote to the creditor offering an amount less than that of the debt in full settlement of the debt and enclosing a draft for that amount. The creditor cashed and retained the proceeds of the draft and afterwards brought an action against the debtor for the balance of the debt.

precedents.cited_proposition: Creditor who cashes and retains a lesser amount offered specifically in full settlement is bound by the terms and cannot sue the debtor for the balance.
precedents.cited_holding: the creditor must be takan to have accepted the amount received by him on the terms upon which it was offered and therefore he companyld number maintain the action.
